context: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the regulatory body whose standards (510(k), Recalls) define the data and workflows of this system.
A premarket submission made to FDA to demonstrate that the device to be marketed is at least as safe and effective as a legally marketed device. One of the 4 core datasets.
The core technology utilizing autonomous LLM agents (defined in `agents.yaml`) to perform complex tasks like document analysis and risk assessment without constant human intervention.
A method of removing or correcting products that are in violation of laws administered by the FDA. The system visualizes recall severity and history.
Adverse Drug/Device Reaction (Medical Device Reporting). A database of adverse events that the system cross-references to identify safety signals.
Global Unique Device Identification Database. Used by the system to retrieve standardized device attributes like single-use, sterile, or MRI safety status.
The open-source Python framework used to build the "WOW" interactive web interface, chosen for its rapid development capabilities and data support.
The cloud hosting platform targeted for deployment, providing an accessible environment for the Streamlit application.
The specific color theme (#FF7F50) used to highlight critical regulatory keywords (e.g., "Warning", "Predicate") in the UI and processed documents.
Optical Character Recognition. A critical pipeline step where the system converts scanned PDF pages into machine-readable text using tools like Tesseract or Vision LLMs.
A system mode designed to iterate through large directories of PDF files, performing automated trimming and summarization to create a master index.
The configuration file that defines the persona, model, system prompt, and capabilities of each AI Agent available in the system.
Master Table of Contents. An aggregated document generated by the Batch Processor that combines summaries of all files in a project for high-level analysis.
The process of removing irrelevant pages (like cover sheets) from a PDF before OCR or analysis to save tokens and improve relevance.
A cloud provider used for high-intelligence tasks (e.g. GPT-4o) including complex reasoning and vision-based OCR.
A cloud provider (Google) offering models like Gemini 1.5 Pro/Flash, utilized for their large context windows and cost-efficiency in document processing.
The standardized output format for all system reports and document conversions, enabling easy editing and formatting with Coral highlights.
Advanced AI models (e.g., GPT-4o Vision) used to "read" PDF pages as images, preserving table structure and layout better than traditional OCR.
A Python library used in the backend for basic PDF manipulation tasks such as reading page counts and splitting/trimming files.
A fast string matching library used by the search engine to perform fuzzy keyword matching across the multiple JSON datasets.
